The main wire set that I call the Umbilical Cord on my FlashForge Creator Pro is bent over to one side and rubs on the plexiglass top. This is annoying. I've been using it for a few weeks now without any problems. Im going to add clips instead the zip tie as soon as possible.

description.text: impossible object printing withouth support and at once. Objeto impreso sin soportes y de una sola vez.

Credit Goes to imagineering4 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1261720) for rear cable conduit.

I just incorporate my designed bed harness to reduce wire strain on Y-Axis cables and tidy up the wirings. I use two M3 bolt and nuts to lock the harness and inside a case there's a holes for cable tie to secure the wires. For the wire management, I use a plastic split loom tubing to hold the cables.

Please note: for the bed harness holder, I designed it to fit on my current setup, considering the placement of wire and solder. The soldering points act as a stopper for the wire harness with the help for 2 M3 bolts to securely clip it on the print bed. You may need to measure actual setup on your printer and made some adjustments.

Lastly this is still work on progress since I'm still working to modify the rear cable conduit to move the wires at the center.

If you like the thing please share with us.

description.text:
I designed a compact carriage for the E3D Titan/v6 combo that replaces the front carriage of a C/D-Bot type printer. This carriage is compatible with the default rear carriage, but you will need to print an offset fan mount (inlcuded). I've also included an optional smoother flowing (I have no data to back this up...) fan duct that's compatible with either carriage design (original bowden or this).

This carriage relocates the nozzle up and to the right (looking from the front), as well as loses about 15mm of Y travel, so you'll want to take that into account when modifying the firmware travel limits and slicer offsets.

I've also included a pair of spacer replacements that will allow you to mount a BLTouch probe on the bottom of the carriage such that you don't lose any more travel. I included a copy of my configuration.h from repetier-firmware version 0.92; I made the switch because I was having some issues getting bed-leveling to work properly in Marlin.

As an extra bit, I've included a copy of the full extruder assembly in STEP format if anyone wants to modify things in a real CAD software.

comments.author: oluwasegun

comments.text: On the DRV8825, motor current is double the voltage reference, so yes, 0.55 volts is too high. You'll need to turn it down to 0.5 or lower in order to keep below your stepper's 1A current rating. Handy tutorial: https://www.pololu.com/blog/484/video-setting-the-current-limit-on-pololu-stepper-motor-driver-carriers

print_settings.Notes:: This is a very easy print. I've printed about eight of them without any major issues.

description.text:
This is a relief representation of the NASA Mars Curiosity rover.

The base of the rover has three small snap-fit connectors. The wheels snap onto the base and turn freely.

The back side of the body of the rover has two cylindrical indentations for fridge magnets.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Resolution:

0.1mm layers

Infill:

80%

Notes:

This is a very easy print. I've printed about eight of them without any major issues.

Wheel attachment and magnet insertion

Wheels:

The base of the rover has three upward-facing cantilever posts. The three wheels have a central hole, and two sides: one with a smaller diameter hole, one with a larger diameter hole.

To attach the wheels:

1) Wait for the print to cool before attaching the wheels. (10 minutes or so should do it. Just wait long enough for the posts to be solid enough to withstand the insertion process.)

2) Place the rover on a flat, solid surface.

3) Take one wheel and orient it over a post with the smaller diameter opening facing downward.

4) Gently press the wheel onto the post (rotating the wheel while pressing downward may help) until it snaps onto the post. Try not to apply too much lateral pressure, as the posts are thin and prone to snapping: just press downward.

Fridge magnets:

1) Acquire at least two neodymium magnets with the following dimensions:

Diameter: 10mm / 0.4 inches
Thickness: 2mm / 0.08 inches

I got mine from a place called K&J Magnets (ZD2).

2) Insert some glue into one of the holes (Gorlla Glue works great), making sure to coat the sides as well as the bottom.

3) Insert the magnet and press down a bit. Optionally, cover the magnet with another thin layer of glue to seal it into the hole.

4) Wait for the glue to set, then do the same with the other magnet.

(Note: You can do both of them at the same time, but the risk is that the magnets are strong and closely spaced... they may attract each other so strongly that they pull each other out of the holes. Dealing with two strong magnets, not just magnetically connected but also coated in glue, is a pain!)

I used TinkerCad exclusively for this model.

I started with a basic snap-fit rotating connection: just a post and a rotatable connector. That led to some ideas of what I could do with it, and I ended up with this model.

I found a side-view image of the Mars Curiosity Rover, and just put together some geometric shapes that resembled it. (Some artistic license was taken with scale and features - this model is supposed to be cute and fun, not necessarily an accurate representation!)

glued 2 of these to the inside of each inner gun mount disc and added a cheap spring from the hardware store so the guns are now posable. I made this for the 150% larger model I did so you would prob want to reduce the size by 40% when you print it.

description.text:
This is a living hinge that uses a tessellation of child objects to create an array of cutouts. This allows for very artistic living hinges that may or may not work. This thing is customizable to show off the features of the program. It is not intended to be printed (although of course you could). The idea is for the user to create a pattern which is cut out by a laser cutter or engraver.

In this program the object is a character which can be input by the user, the size of the hinge, the array type (square, hexagonal or triangular), the character, the amount of whitespace padding, the rotation of the characters, as well as centering are all customizable.

If you download the .scad file, it will come with many examples, and includes all the functions in thing:1736879

Please leave any comments, bug reports or feature requests in the comments, I would like to get this added to the OpenSCAD standard library.

Notes:

This is not intended to be printed, but instead to be laser cut from flat stock.

description.text:
Kids can learn so much more about money and math when they do it with hands-on kinesthetic learning. Using Money Montessori with real or imitation coins, students can try building monetary values using coins.

These math plates are simple and straightforward so that students can use them in breakout groups independently without constant supervision or assistance from an educator.

These plates are designed to be similar in shape and size to real United States dollar bill currency. The examples are for $1 and $2 however these may be expanded to $5, $10, $20, etc.

Smaller values may be put together with coins side-by-side in 2D. When larger numbers of coins are required, we leverage 3D modeling to have a structure that supports stacking coins in 3D.

The $1 money plate was designed in SketchUp. The $2 money plate was designed in TinkerCAD. No particular reason but just to tinker around with different software.

($5, $10, $20 are pending...)

Building Additional Plates

To build additional plates of other monetary values, use the following coin dimensions for stacking vertically or placing side-by-side:

Cent Diameter: 0.750 inches/19.05mm
Cent Thickness: 1.52mm

Nickel Diameter: 0.835 inches/21.21mm
Nickel Thickness: 1.95mm

Dime Diameter: 0.705 inches/24.26mm
Dime Thickness: 1.75mm

Quarter Dollar Diameter: 0.955 inches/24.26 mm
Quarter Dollar Thickness: 1.75 mm

Half Dollar Diameter: 1.205 inches/30.61mm
Half Dollar Thickness: 2.15mm

Presidential $1 Diameter: 1.043 inches/26.49mm
Presidential $1 Thickness: 2.00mm

Native American $1 Coin Diameter: 1.043 inches/26.49mm
Native American $1 Coin Thickness: 2.00mm

Dollar Bill Width: 2.61 inches
Dollar Bill Length: 6.14 inches
Dollar Bill Thickness: .0043 inches

Cent Diameter: 0.750 inches/19.05mm Cent Thickness: 1.52mm Nickel Diameter: 0.835 inches/21.21mm Nickel Thickness: 1.95mm Dime Diameter: 0.705 inches/24.26mm Dime Thickness: 1.75mm Quarter Dollar Diameter: 0.955 inches/24.26 mm Quarter Dollar Thickness: 1.75 mm Half Dollar Diameter: 1.205 inches/30.61mm Half Dollar Thickness: 2.15mm Presidential $1 Diameter: 1.043 inches/26.49mm Presidential $1 Thickness: 2.00mm

Project Name: Money Plates (Montessori)

This project uses money as the medium for practice. Real United States currency in coins can be used as well as imitation plastic coins from Lakeshore Learning or Learning Resources.

These plates can be used in traditional classroom environments as well as open exploration style Montessori. They are simple enough for a students to experiment with independently.

Overview & Background

Educators will find a few example STL of the Money Plates Montessori concept. Educators may design additional plates using this concept.

Objectives

Students will have hands-on kinesthetic practice with currency practicing using smaller amounts of currency to create equivalent larger values of currency.

This practice will give them a fun way to exercise their skills in addition and multiplication.

Audiences

In the spirit of Montessori, every learner can explore money using these plates at their own pace and interest level.

For students following Common Core State Standards, Money Montessori would match most appropriately to Grade 2.

Money Montessori plates could also be used for differentiation in Grade 1 with students who are more accelerated in math and require extra challenges that they may complete independently.

Subjects

Money Plates Montessori is focused primary on mathematics development.

Skills Learned (Standards)

CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.2.MD.C.8
Solve word problems involving dollar bills, quarters, dimes, nickels, and pennies, using $ and ¢ symbols appropriately. Example: If you have 2 dimes and 3 pennies, how many cents do you have?

Work with equal groups of objects to gain foundations for multiplication.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.2.OA.C.3
Determine whether a group of objects (up to 20) has an odd or even number of members, e.g., by pairing objects or counting them by 2s; write an equation to express an even number as a sum of two equal addends.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.2.OA.C.4
Use addition to find the total number of objects arranged in rectangular arrays with up to 5 rows and up to 5 columns; write an equation to express the total as a sum of equal addends.

Lesson/Activity

Duration:
Individual plates can be issued to students in a traditional classroom to match the mathematics curriculum.

For Montessori exploration or "choice time" Money Plates can take anywhere from 1-30 minutes depending on the number of plates used. (Additional Money Plate .stl files are pending...)

Preparation: Educators will need some real or imitation coins for students to use.

References

Example imitation coins are available from Learning Resources through Amazon:
https://www.amazon.com/Learning-Resources-Currency-X-Change-Activity/dp/B0013CNLWS/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1472668678

United States Mint Coin Specifications
https://www.usmint.gov/about_the_mint/?action=coin_specifications

Additional information on United States Currency from the Department of the Treasury

Denominations:
https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/faqs/Currency/Pages/denominations.aspx

Production and Circulation:
https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/faqs/Coins/Pages/edu_faq_coins_production.aspx

Complete index of United States Mint Coin Sizes including versions that are no longer printed:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Mint_coin_sizes

Rubric & Assessment

Students who have successfully completed each Math Plate Puzzle will have a solution to show their teacher.

Handouts & Assets

Money Plates (Montessori) are designed to work without the need for worksheets however they work well complementing standard math curriculum.

If you love film photography and uses 120 film for outdoor photography like I do, this "120 film rolls holder" maybe useful for carrying unexposed and Exposed films.  
Unlike 135 film, 120 films do not come with plastic cases or a metal shell. The risk of smashing the film roll or leaking lights on the exposed rolls is quite high.  
This film holder has four compartment for 4 rolls of films.Each compartment has their own cap and is tight-fit to the opening of the compartment.   
By adding a label on the side of the holder, the hole designed for the strings on the caps can act as an indicator to let you know which compartments contain the fresh roll of unexposed film.  
You are mostly welcome to leave comments or to suggest an improvement. I will modify the design to make everyone benefit from this film holder.  
Please use the darkest materials ( Black is the best ) and most dense layers to make the holder light proof.   
Just a reminder - Always open the film or the film holder in shadow.

To remix this I used tinkercad and printed many times until I got everything lined up. TinkerCad is fairly clumsy to do this sort of thing but I haven't mastered anything better. My main complaints are how frustrating it is to size a hole precisely with a mouse. Supposedly you can type in the dimensions but that didn't work for me (possibly just ignorance). I hope these help someone else out!

comments.text: I went to a lead screw so had to adjust the config for distance per step but it was pretty easy to do...main thing on the part print here is does you threaded rod or lead screw fit inside the ball bearing
comments.author: riftware

comments.text: hi i have als a pro c with z axis m8 treath can you replace it without any hassle with a tr8 2mm pitch?
comments.author: mab500

comments.text: Sorry - I never noticed this comment in here.   The answer is probably too late for you but it was fairly easy for me.  The main thing is you have to update your marlin config file because the amount the z axis moves per revolution is different between a lead screw and a threaded rod.    There are tutorials on how to adjust that config though so its not too hard to do.

title: Single Filament Monitor & Extruder Mount for Delta 3D printer.

description.text:
This thing is a mount for the Tunell Filament Monitor and Extruder for a delta 2020 printer using a Bowden tube extruder.

The Tunell Filament monitor is available at http://www.toybuilderlabs.com. it pauses the print when the filament runs out or becomes tangled/jammed..

Just the monitor bracket itself is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:345216

slots are use to provide some adjustability and aid in aligning the filament monitor and the extruder.

This thing works perfectly with my filament spool holder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1295883

Printer:

kossel delta 2020

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

30%

Assembly
  1. attach the monitor to the monitor bracket using m3x10mm screws.
  2. attach the extruder support and extruder mount to the extruder bracket using m3x20mm screws and m3 nuts. the extruder mount provides for side to side adjustment.
  3. attach the monitor bracket to the extruder bracket using m3x20mm screws and m3 nylock nuts. the monitor bracket provides for front to back adjustment.
  4. attach the extruder to the extruder mount using the extended m3x45mm screws for the extruder.
  5. Fine tune the alignment between the filament monitor and the extruder using the slots in the brackets
  6. attach the extruder bracket to the 2020 frame using m3x14mm screws and m3 t-nuts.
  7. route the cable from the monitor to the board. I used the groove in the 2020 to the outside of the printer and routed the limit switch and extruder motor cables

author: sysimgrp

description.text:
Here in Chile, getting ABS is expensive as hell, with shipment and taxes I easily get each kilo per $100 usd or more.
So I thought about making a very cheap extruder machine that everyone can build to make filament from ABS pellets (I can get 1 kg per 2-3 usd in my country). Right now, I have a big drill bit, a tube and I am making concept tests with a heat gun, nothing very serious, so the model probably will change (the first peltier cell arrived broken :( so ... 1 extra month waiting for other one)

comments.text: A cheap source for the auger would be a plant bulb auger/drill bit. They are designed to drill a 28mm (1 1/8") x 450mm (18") hole to plant tulip bulbs. They can be had for ~$10.00 and found at graden centers.

comments.text: Looks much better than the drill bit (I have to see the availability of that part here, the drill bit 22 mm cost me 22 usd, not as expensive as I expected) but not very efficient displacing the pellets backwards

After several iterations this seems to be working for me. I haven't printed with it yet, but all the parts are mounted. If you downloaded an early (non z probe) version of this file, dont use it.

V2- fixed interference between chimera mounting bolts and plastic part
-added zprobe holder

This fits on the standard D-bot parts. You have to attach this piece to the printer before attaching hotend or else the bottom two screws cannot be connected.

title: Da Vinci Jr Y-axis Mounting Plate for Makerslide mod

description.text:
Work in progress! Untested! Just the STL for now until the design is completed.

This is a mounting plate for replacing the Da Vinci Jr Y-axis assembly with a redesigned Makerslide-based carriage.

The two center mounting holes attach to T-nuts in the bottom of the Makerslide V-slot from below, then the whole thing is mounted using the stock screws where the old Y-axis used to attach.

The giant hole is where the Y-axis stepper and idlers are placed in the bottom of the frame.

description.text:
This is a universal Picatinny Mount.
Unlike every other mount out there, it utilizes a CAM and a ziptie to lock it in place instead of hardware.

The "flare" in the ziptie is what locks the upper section of the cam and the ziptie head is placed on the bottom of the mount (not the top)
Print the cam flat.

A very basic idea that will hopefully be useful for mounting things either permanently or temporarily.

It is very much a work in progress but it does work in its current form.

UPDATED: 9/1/16
Beefed up the cam and slightly modified the pin.

print_settings.Notes:: The higher than average infill is used, as the M3 hardware is designed to go into smaller than average holes, to avoid the use of a tap and to make the project easier. It may be slightly difficult to start the bolts into the holes, but it is completely possible to thread them into the holes.

description.text: These are the pieces necessary to turn any sized sheet of polycarbonate into a wall mountable dry erase board. The original design uses M3 hardware to connect the polycarbonate to the plastic pieces. The marker holders are designed for thin Expo brand dry erase markers, as well as the eraser. The dry erase board has Velcro pads under each foot in order to be removable from the wall and taken anywhere.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Mendel90

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The higher than average infill is used, as the M3 hardware is designed to go into smaller than average holes, to avoid the use of a tap and to make the project easier. It may be slightly difficult to start the bolts into the holes, but it is completely possible to thread them into the holes.

If you are having trouble with getting the bolts to tap into the plastic

For those who use imperial drill bits, I recommend using a 3/32" (~2.38mm) drill bit to make the minimum sized hole for the bolt to catch, if it is not already at this diameter. Increase this to a size 7/64" (~2.78mm) drill bit if still having difficulty.

How this design came to be

The design was made after seeing many TV shows with the use of see through dry erase boards being used. After much research, I discovered that polycarbonate actually works quite well as a dry erase surface, as well as being see through, (and incredibly impact resistant/bulletproof).

3D printable kazoo instrument, just add wax paper!
Just print, assemble the parts, add wax paper, and you're ready to hum.

For full kazoo in 1 print use the Kazoo_All.STL file & make sure to use exterior support, for the valve to print properly. Each part is also available in a separate file, only the valve needs support, the cap and body are fine to print without. To play;
â€¢ Insert the valve into the main body
â€¢ Cut a small piece of wax paper (about 1" square) & place it on top of the valve
â€¢ Gently push the cap over the wax paper and onto the valve
â€¢Â For best sound, hum into the larger end
â€¢ Enjoy! Object height: 119mm
STP and STL formats available.

remixed_from.title: Magnetic Kossel effector e3d compatible (45mm centers)

description.text:
based on a request, and my own personal experiments, i have taken another look at the diamond head design. this design is experimental and untested. This version now includes:

  • magnetic arm configuration, matching 45mm width @ the centers (see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:932914 )
  • V3 moves the arm stumps to the top of the effector, thereby giving the arms full clearance from any potential obstacles.
  • v3a continues to have the arm mounts at 8 mm from the top, in case the 40mm fan gets in the way. or, if you prefer to have the arms closer to the nozzle.
  • refactored the fan mount to a 40mm fan. the 50mm fan mount was obtrusive
  • added compatible mounting plate for a BLTouch experimental z-probe that i recently ordered, to give z-probes another chance. others can extend this for their own z-probe models if they so choose.

i won't get to printing one for a few weeks, as i'm rebuilding my delta for the magnetic arms, but I would love to get some feedback on this on how well this works if anyone does give it a try. drop me a line and a pic

Delta Printer Ball Joint Housing.
I have an FLSun Delta Printer and have had some minor issues with the ball joints on the arms so have decided to pull the balls out and make a new housing for them.

The balls are approximately 8mm in diameter and snap in to the housing quite well.
I used ABS to print them but eventually will replace this with Nylon.

Removing the balls from the old aluminium casing is prety easy, I used a small bearing with an ID that was larger than the ball, then a bolt and hit the bolt with a hammer a couple of times. not too hard and the ball pops out.

I put the new ABS plastic casing on the wooden bench and using the bot tapped it with a hammer in to the new housing.

description.text: I wanted a convenient way to put a 12V A23 size battery in a container where the wires were tightly connected. Insert the battery into the main cylinder, and put a little aluminum foil on both sides to maximize conduction. Then, insert the positive and negative wires into the corresponding holes and you are done! Note: the picture shows more than just the cylindrical battery pack. It shows it being used inside the LED setup from Master Chief's helmet from Halo 4 (http://www.thingiverse.com/make:51704).

Sorry, my blender software doesn't make it easy to export an STL in the correct orientation and ready to print.  
So, please center the STL objects before printing. Also, print the "cover" piece upside down from how I uploaded it.  
2 cover pieces + 1 main holder/cylinder piece = a full working battery pack!
This is a quick OpenSCAD file that lets you make a spinner toy from 4 of the same sized bearings. Tell it the diameter and the thickness of your bearings and it will make a three armed "spinner."

title: Mechanical Z Endstop for DjDemonD/AndreasL Dual z axis smartrapcore alu

description.text:
This is an adjustable z-max endstop holder for a standard endstop 1.2 board. It can be retrofitted (using superglue or acetone if printed in ABS) to the lower front bracket of the dual z axis.

The second part is an extension which can be glued to the unused belt clip on the left side of the front z carriage, to press the endstop.

This has come about as ABL seems to be a bit of a waste of time with this axis on this printer, the bed can be easily manually levelled and is quite consistent.

If changing to using z-max endstop and using marlin 1.1.0 RC then change configuration.h to homing direction z =1 (max)

Then set manual home positions z to your full z height (mine is 170mm).

After that I just used babystep z on the first print and used m206 to enter the home offset. (Nb. if the nozzle was 1mm too high the m206 z would be 1.)

author: DjDemonD

description.text:
After purchasing a nifty metal dice set on Amazon I read in some of the reviews that it would be best to store them in a partitioned container to prevent the heavy dice from bumping together and causing dents/scratches.

Updates:
I changed the shape from 12-sided to round, increased the size of each chamber by an eighth of an inch, and reduced the clearance between the dice and the top of the container.

I also included a version with a dragon design inset on the top. It isn't my design, as it was generated from an image I found on a Bing image search, but it originates from this article:

http://blog.endernews.com/2013/02/exclusive-first-look-at-dragon-army-logo.html

It's apparently the logo for Dragon army from Ender's game, but I just selected it because it looks cool.

I consider this design to be mostly complete. One warning if you print the dragon-emblem version: use supports, and be very careful when removing them. The bottom of the inset design is VERY thin so you may inadvertently punch a hole in it if you aren't careful.

description.text:
Hey folks!

For all of you who like board games I figured I'd upload this design that my girlfriend and I put together.

To print the full game, print the following in two different colours (or paint one of the sets, maybe):

1 x Bee
2 x Beetle
2 x Spider
3 x Ant
3 x Grasshopper

No supports needed of course.

If you happen to print yourself a set, please post a photo, I'd love to know this is being enjoyed! Thanks.

UPDATE!

Hey there, so due to a request - thanks for the interest ljclark1 ;) - I've added 3 expansion pieces to the game. You can track down the rules for how to play with these pieces online. They include: The Mosquito (who borrows the powers of the piece it's touching), The Ladybug (who can move 3 spaces, 2 on top of pieces and one down to an empty space), and the Pill Bug (who can move other pieces it is touching!)

Same print settings will work for the new ones as the old.

Have fun, and enjoy!

remixed_from.title: Parametric Involute  Bevel and Spur Gears

title: Spur and Gear for Vaterra Ascender

description.text:
This is a derivative of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3575.

I made this to explore different ratios for my Vaterra Ascender.

With Openscad, it's pretty simply to create whatever spur-gear combinations you want.

Instructions :

  1. measure distance between the centers of the spur and the pinion you have now

  2. set DISTANCE_BETWEEN_CENTERS_ACCORDINGLY

  3. set TEETH_1 and TEETH_2 as you wish

  4. modify CIRCULAR_PITCH_DEF until gears mesh correctly; you might want to modify SPUR_ROTATE_DEGREES so that you can see the teeth mesh

title: Messerschmit Bf 109 H/F wing test part

description.text:
Test part of right wing of our Messerchmitt Bf 109 H and F

Give a look to attached PDF/VIDEO userguide

We still trying move things further, so this project is full of other improvements
for better durability , easier assembly , better geometry solution and
so on..., we hope you enjoy it, although this print may test your competencies
to and quality of your printer (welcome to thin wall printing)

Our latest project so far... the Best one
Excels with perfect flight behavior , we are really excited about this
A large speed range achieved from 30 to 150 kph

We recommend Simplify3D slicer for this project
check for next STL files:
http://3dlabprint.com
http://www.facebook.com/3dlabprintface
https://youtu.be/8oC442DtZPY?list=PLcpmwpTOtMxSkbuZn319MSOnlVmRjAs56

comments.text: Verry well made. I just start printing using included S3D factory files, just adjust temperature and starting G-code for my printer. Parts of wing fits well and look great .Thanks.
comments.author: SpasT

comments.text:
Test file has no internal structure, ribs, in Cura, regardless of settings I try. Something is messed up. Cannot even attempt to print.
I see your STL files are not valid, as investigated by Slicer Developers...
https://github.com/alexrj/Slic3r/issues/3560#issuecomment-258671975
comments.author: ackerman76

comments.text:
This file prints with no issue with Simplify 3D when you use the right settings for your printer.
If you properly read the documentation first you would have found that Slic3r cannot print the stl files created by 3Dlabprint, because they use single wall printing to save weight and produce a flyable model. I haven't tried Cura with this file, but I am not sure it has all the functionality needed to fine tweak the settings and outputs the best possible gcode for these kind of prints.
Unfortunately it is quite common today that people do not read the documentation, do not try to understand how things are done and designed and just complain...
It took me a bit of trial and error to properly tune my Duplicator 6, but it is now printing the complete ME BF 109 model and the result is stunningly beautiful.
Glad I bought both the Spitfire and the ME 109 from their store :)
Jeff
comments.author: ackerman76

comments.text: I've printed many other items with one outer wall and that is not the problem. Their CAD files themselves are invalid by CAD standards due to the improper interface between walls and inner ribs.
comments.author: jeffT67

comments.text:
had the same prblem with all these files, after uninstalling cura 3164, and reinstalling 15046 it worked perfect .
problem is definitly in cura.

If you print in ABS you'll have to scale even further accordingly. Maybe 1.075 or so. You can cancel the print after the first couple of layers and test how it fits, then rescale and try again until you find the perfect fit.

The sticks used on the picture are Hawk-RC, but it should fit over most other sticks as well (minus the super-fat-thumb ones I guess). http://www.hawk-creation.com/index.php?route=product/product&product_id=3177

description.text:
Detailed build and use photos can be found here: http://imgur.com/a/SPqIG

As I mentioned recently (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1739203) a few local ladies and I have been trying to get together an FPV drone racing club. While we've sort of gotten micro-drones taken care of with the above low cost VTX mount, we still needed displays.

Goggles are really best but when we tried out a cheap pair we hit a snag- you can't see anything with them on and none of the girls really wanted to be blindfolded in public. I think there are ones with a camera pass though? But they are way out of our budget. Being blindfolded at an event the middle of a crowd of guys was going to make focusing on racing tough (even if everyone was totally well behaved). So I decided to look at our options..

We need to keep costs low because I really want to use drone racing as a gateway to Maker culture for local girls, so all the solutions we're looking at are in the $50USD range. So far 5 inch displays mounted on tripods or the remote controls have not really worked out. I came up with this. I can use it pretty well but so far no one else has tested it.

If you like this and want to see more of my projects, or a bit of my life in Shenzhen, China you can look here:

►Twitter: https://twitter.com/RealSexyCyborg
►My Photo Albums: http://sexycyborg.imgur.com
►YouTube: http://www.youtube.com/c/SexyCyborg
►My FAQ: http://pastebin.com/V3474kYs

remixed_from.author: syvwlch
remixed_from.title: Racheting Drum Intermediate Gear for Clockathon #2 Test Jig - FIXED

title: Radial Load Bearing Ratchet Proof of Concept

description.text:
This is a first attempt at modifying RustedRobot's ratchet design so that it can carry significant radial loads, e.g. from the weight hanging off the power drum of a clock.
The current design relies on the ratchet arms to carry the load, but they have to remain thin and springy as well... So far in the clock, this has required a complicated and thick part which must use spokes that reach over the inner wheel to reach the shaft.
Hopefully with this refinement, the ratchet can carry large radial loads, be contained in a single gear's thickness and perhaps even be printed in place.

This is a derivative of RustedRobot's fine ratchet library, and it is only a proof of concept. The code is very dirty and changing any parameter will likely break it at this point!
Could someone print one in ABS, and see if this works as a ratchet? I'm not sure I made the arms thin enough to bend out of the way properly.

The printer is inspired by the following printers ultimaker/corecube/Ingentis, I liked various design aspects then opened up a cad program and set about designing and printing the bits and also re-designing things that didn't work as well as it should of
I did keep the xy spacings as the ultimaker 1 to allow people to use 3rd party parts, The pulley system I worked out on paper and tried a few designs before I was happy with what I had, I also thought it wold be better to have both ballsrews driven by the one driver to lower any chance that dual motors would be slightly out of sync, For the pictures I will see if i can find something a little closer for you

comments.text: Gotcha, I was looking at using a 500mm leadscrew with 40mm machined to 8mm on the bottom. do you think increasing the height or have a shorter bottom 8mm section would have any impact on the design?

comments.text: You would need to increase the 4 vertical openbeams and 4 linear z rods to allow for the longer length but other than that you will not have to change the design, im using a 78oz nema 17 steppers and it has no issues with moving any axis, im also not needing to max out the drivers either, let me know when your at the stage of needing to setup your marlin and I can send you my configuration.h , mine is running happily at 100/150mm/sec with great results

description.text:
This is the first object I've ever designed from scratch, it's basic, it serves it's intended purpose but it could be better (I lack the skills at this stage to improve it)

This is a replacement mouthpiece for a Kangertech DripBox e-cigarette. The standard one tends to snap and crack easily when dropped so I designed this as a replacement and with a nicer curved profile rather than the flat sides the original had.

Due to the size of it, you may have issues printing this on some printers, I had to print with supports but found the supports difficult to remove without damaging the rest of it. It's usable though and my printer is purely to blame for the issues I had. I'm using a 0.4mm nozzle on a Prusa i3, I think a smaller nozzle would provide far better results.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Notes:

Doesn't print well with a 0.4mm nozzle and no print fan, but it is usable. Would benefit from a smaller nozzle and a print fan. Will require rotating in your slicer software to print with the base downwards, not sure why I can't get it to export from Fusion 360 in the correct orientation.

I printed with supports, I found them very difficult to remove without damaging the print. I used a thin but strong flat-ended knife (it was pointy, but the tip snapped off) to put in wherever it would fit and twist the supports out.

Designed in Fusion 360. Designed as a flat cross-section in the required shape, revolved around the Z axis then used a cuboid shape to make the airflow cutouts near the bottom. All measurements are as close to the original part as possible and it fits the e-cigarette very well, the original O-rings also fit perfectly in the grooves.

comments.text: Nice design dude!
comments.author: DogFight

comments.text: Thanks :) I found it a bit tough to print as it's so small, when I removed the supports it tended to take parts of the mouthpiece with it but soon I will be getting some soluble support material so hopefully that will make it easier to do

title: Emax Nighthawk 200 Multi-Purpose Runcam2 Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a 20° angled mount for a Runcam2-type action cam designed to fit an Emax Nighthawk 200 frame. It's designed to be sturdy, light, and make the best possible use of space by integrating additional features - hence 'multi-purpose'.

Features:

  • cam to be strapped down with a velcro lock strap (16-20 mm width, e.g. a small Scorpion Strap)
  • cam is kept from sliding out in front
  • follows original front board outline exactly, uses original screws
  • houses a Lemon Satellite or similar (need to decase if used with Loc8tor)
  • mounts antenna tubes (dia 3.3 mm or fit with shrink tubes/duct tape)
  • mounts an LED headlight (remove plastic rear, seal with shrink tubing and lock with an M3 set screw through the front nub from below)

If you would like different angles or other modifications, please feel free to contact me and I'll try my best to help you out. I appreciate any comments and suggestions.

This is a successor to Thing 1550114 with some minor improvements, but without the space for a Loc8tor (which is great in theory, but in reality is an expensive piece of sh1t that never really works - don't get one!).

comments.text: Great mount, thanks! I mounted it to my Vortex 285 quad.

print_settings.Notes:: I used ABS, not sure how well PLA will part from the hot glue.

description.text:
I use XT60 connectors on a lot of leads with thinner wires so I can power stuff like dinghy inflators and strings of 12v lights using standard LiPo batteries. I tend to find though that the thinner wires tend to break on the connector at the solder joint.

I'm aware of the plasti-dip treatment but that can be a bit messy and time consuming so I thought of making a mold that encases the XT60 connector that I could squirt hot glue into to make a kind of strain relief, I say "kind of" because the cable it still stressed where it leaves the end of the relief as I figured my chances of prising the part out of the mold with delicate relief marks were about zero.

This works better than I thought, it's best to get the glue gun as hot as it can be, then squirt the glue between the two wires first with a couple of firm squeezes on the trigger, then follow up with one squirt at each side of the wires to complete the joint. If you leave the glue to cool for a couple of minutes then trim the excess away with a knife the results are fairly neat. The halves on my prints with eSun ABS come apart surprisingly easily and leave a nice joint. Sanding the mating surface of the XT60 improves the joint.

Note the same mold works for both male and female XT60 connectors.

comments.text: Hi, thanks for the feedback. I did try a version that had a longer neck but the problem was that it made it really difficult to get the hot snot forced all the way down so drastically increased the chances of air pockets down by the solder lugs. I'll re-visit the design at some point maybe to provide an inlet channel for the hot glue on the side or something, then the neck can be longer and you would have a better chance of a successful mold and only leaving an injection point on the side you have to cut off, or something.

Shear is a guillotine style cigar cutter that uses a standard, utility knife razor blade to do the cutting. The advantage of this design is the replaceable blade. I chose to use the utility blade because it is an extremely easy to find and affordable razor. Only half of the razor is used to cut, so just like a utility knife, you can simply flip the blade once it is dull to have a new, sharp edge. This makes this design superior to many conventional cigar cutters, which become nearly useless after the fixed blade becomes dull. The only additional hardware required is a 6-32 x 3/8 machine screw and nut. These can be found in packages containing 14 sets at many hardware stores including Lowe's and Home Depot for about $1.00 or, if you prefer metric: There is another version that uses a 10mm M3 screw and M3 nut Enjoy!

  • A Relative Design project.
    http://www.relativedesign.us/blog

    • See all our projects Here:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/tag:relative_design

There is one bridged hole that will need to be drilled or cleaned out with an x-acto knife. Assembly Instructions:
  • Place a clean utility blade into the Carriage. It will snap into place.
  • Place the Carriage with the installed utility blade onto the rails of the Frame. Slide the carriage down so that the blade is at the bottom of the Frame.
  • Insert the recessed tab of the Lid into the Frame, then push the rest of the Lid down into the Frame. It will snap into place.
  • Place the nut into the hexagonal hole in the Lid.
  • Complete the assembly by inserting the machine screw into the Frame and fasten all parts together.
    • Your Snip cigar cutter is now ready to use!

Like its predecessors, this Tinkertoy-compatible bearing system uses ten 4.5mm BB's to provide smoother rotation than the stock wheels included with a Tinkertoy set. The center bore is just a little loose on a Tinkertoy rod (not renowned for their precision diameters in the first place) so if you really need the bearing to stick fast I recommend using a little piece of painters' tape around the rod. It's modeled in three parts for ease of assembly, but you'll need to super glue the two halves together.

title: Expo White Board Pen holder for 8 pens

description.text:
This is an Expo White board pen holder for 8 pens. The pens are staggered to help take up a little less horizontal space - and maybe because I thought it looked cool. The holder is also leaning out slightly so that it is easier to grab and can hold an eraser on top.

Recap:

  1. Holds 8 pens
  2. Angled (30 degrees) so it holds an eraser on top and makes it easier to grab pens.
  3. Staggered pens

I now have a 4 slot version here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1751010

*For Maximum Feng Shui make sure that you order your pens in ROYGBIV fashion. :)

**If you have kids or professional wrestlers around your white board I suggest hitting a stud when mounting or using strong dual sided adhesive.

Printer:

PowerSpec Ultra 3D

No

20%

Notes:

The infill probably doesn't count for much in this design.

With the top circles sitting on the print bed they will slightly flare - making the pen insertion a little tight at first. I rotated my leatherman's needle nose tip into each hole with a little pressure for about 15 seconds to fix this.

author: Jimbotron

description.text:
I have a great paddle key for home but I didnt want to trust it lasting long while mobile / portable / camping etc etc. So I did up the following. It has worked out quite well and I made 20 contacts the first day it was constructed.

Pictured below is the knee brace bottom which allows you to easily attach the paddles to your leg, but I have a normal bottom model done up as well

I played around with a few designs to get the paddles to return to normal but it turns out the simplest solution was a pen spring. I made a little notch that the spring recessed into. To keep it in place in case you add a drop of crazy glue to the indentation.

what I used for assembly....
3 x #6 1" bolts for the base
2 x #6 1/2" for contacts in the paddles
3 x #6 ring connectors to connect to audio jack
11 x #6 nuts
4 x #4 1/2" to attach top to base
FC Porto - Logo

author: mickouku

description.text:
After ten years the excentric adjustment nuts of the sliding doors of my bath/shower/steam cabin are staring to degenerate.
As the are €5 a piece I recreated them for the 3D printer.
To replace them all you'll need to print 8 sets.
Being not to handy in 3D design I was unable to align the hole of both pieces. So I decided to create one hole in the small part, put the two things together and drill the large part using the hole in the small part.

Wanted a cover to protect the top of the Gen 4 Interface Kit since it has the exposed ribbon cable wiring. This is the first version I attempted...gravity holds it in place and it's not level due to the acrylic plate angle. V2: wider top (covers the wood) and more of a cap than a cover Print whichever one you prefer. This part was made with Tinkercad. Edit the part online at: https://tinkercad.com/things/9r2sBLXVxv8 V2: https://tinkercad.com/things/5U7Wjh98Hsm

Printed on a Thing-O-Matic, Mk6 @ 30% infill, 0.28 layer height
The cap/cover will stay put but I ended up using a little superglue to permanently attach it to the wood top (v2 of the cover that is) as I kept knocking it off while removing prints.
Needed a new badge... printed in two parts... one set with back pins and the other without

title: prusa Anet a8 modular extruder nozzle cooling adapter

description.text:
This is an Anet a8 extruder nozzle fan mod for standard size 80x80 PC fan.

There are tons of adapters like this, but none fits Anet a8 printer, so I have decided to make one.

I have made it modular, so You can easily connect additional accessories to it
It is compatible with factory nozzle cooling ducts (the duct hole mount is the same size and position). All original mounting screws should fit as well.

1 - remove Your existing nozzle duct
2 - unscrew existing nozzle fan
3 - mount Your new bigger fan to this adapter
4 - mount adapter in place of old fan (the fan screws should fit)
5 - mount your old nozzle duct
6 - connect fan cable

Have fun!

This project is in testing phase now..Please comment your problems, print settings,pictures and feature requests.

UPDATE AFTER FIRST PRINT:

Everything seems to be ok except one mounting screw position. It is in wrong place. Has to take bad mesurment ;P.
I will drill the hole in mounting metal thing, becouse i do not want to print it again. But when I finish my upgrade I will upload corrected project. You can print it as is and drill a hole by yopurself, everything else is ok.

I have printed it with:
ABS with 0,1 layer, 5mm brim and support enabled.
Cooler mount laying on the bed.

description.text:
Most cupholders are designed to be attached to the vent ducts or slide into the window rubbers. But having a 4x4 you'll realize that these will only be fixed as far as the first major obstacle to conquer...
This design is very simple, holds the larger cups/bottles (like a bidon or your large milkshake) and most important... you can put three screws trought the bottom for a very rigid fix.

description.text: Bajaj Rouser/Pulsar
used by the USSR in the Second World War.

Servo holders for prop stoppers.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jkWm2fjsuRo

The default servo holders are sized for turnigy TG9Z servos.
I put some heat shrink on end of servo arms and cut the heat shrink to suit props.
Allows prop to force past prop stopper if required.

Use customiser to suit servo used and jpg as reference for variables.

comments.text:
Don't do that. It rather produces wobble instead of fixing it.
The threaded rod is supposed to swing free.
The plain guiding rods are for positioning.
If you force both, it leads to interference.
Why do you think ALL originals have free threaded rods?
comments.author: McSchweg

comments.text: Do you have positive effect after adding this ? in the z-wobble ?
comments.author: dolomitt

comments.text: I found it helped but depends on your setup and  if your rods are running true and x access suports are the same distance from the hotbed.. Many other people have tried them and found them useful. Its a quick print to try and see if they work for you or not.
comments.author: dolomitt

comments.text: Glad you found them useful, thanks for the comment.
